description: Kintor Pharma kicked off bookbuilding with sole sponsor Huatai Financial and global co-ordinators CICC and UBS on May 12. The trio– working alongside bookrunners CCB International, China Everbright Securities, China Renaissance Securities, CMB International and Haitong international– marketed 92.3 m shares at HK $17.80 to HK $20.15 apiece.
text:
The Mainland-based firm hit the market last week, following three other
Chinese healthcare-related issuers that have listed in Hong Kong since March.
The sector has been defiant through the coronavirus crisis, remaining one of
the few popular sectors, running counter-cyclical to downward trending global
financial markets.

Kintor Pharma kicked off bookbuilding with sole sponsor Huatai Financial and
global co-ordinators CICC and UBS on May 12. They took orders for the deal
through a four-day virtual roadshow.

The trio - working alongside bookrunners CCB International, China Everbright
Securities, China Renaissance Securities, CMB International and Haitong
international - marketed 92.3m shares at HK$17.80 to HK$20.15 apiece. The
price guidance meant it could raise anywhere from HK$1.64bn to HK$1.86bn from
the IPO.

Kintor, a clinical-stage novel cancer drug developer, came to the market to
raise funds for developing and commercialising its core products.

To set the IPO on a good base and boost confidence in the deal, the company
placed 48% of the offer with four cornerstone investors. The majority was
taken by Chinese state-backed Zhuhai Gree Financial Investment Management,
which subscribed for $98m.

Entities Cherry Cheeks and Highlight Medical, both indirectly controlled by
pre-IPO investor Stephen Hui Wang, took $7m and $5m, respectively. Chinese
investment bank DFZQ, also known as Orient Securities, claimed $5m of the
deal.

After bookbuilding through to the end of last week, the syndicate wrapped up
the deal. Thanks to the horde of institutional and retail investors, the leads
were able to price the IPO at the top of the range, according to a source
close to the deal.

The institutional book had over 120 long-only investors, healthcare
specialists, hedge funds and high net worth accounts. But Hong Kong retail
investors subscribed their portion of the deal over 500 times, triggering the
full clawback - a mechanism that reallocates stock to retail based on the
level of demand.

The full clawback left just $41m of the IPO for institutional investors. And
with half going to the top 10 accounts - a mix of long only investors and
healthcare specialists - a larger number of investors got zero allocation of
the stock, according to the source.

Kintor's shares will go live at HK$20.15 apiece on the Hong Kong Stock
Exchange on May 22. The deal also includes a 15% greenshoe of 13.9m shares.

The issuer will invest 70% of the IPO proceeds in the development and
commercialisation of its core products. Kintor's lead drug is Proxalutamide,
which is undergoing trials related to prostate cancer and breast cancer.

The firm will also put 20% of the proceeds towards clinical and pre-clinical
stage drug candidates and study projects, and use the balance for working
capital and other general corporate purposes.

Kintor has suffered somewhat from the Covid-19 pandemic, with the forced
closure of its Miami-based clinical trial centre. The company warned in its
prospectus that it cannot assure Covid-19 will have no further impact on its
business, but it does not expect to make any "material deviation" from the
development of its drugs.

Kintor is controlled by co-founder and chief executive Youzhi Tong and co-
founder Chuangxing Guo. Following the IPO, the duo's aggregate stake in the
company has been diluted from 36.84% to 27.64%.

 **

 **New Horizon Health mandates for IPO **

**

Chinese biotechnology firm New Horizon Health has mandated Goldman Sachs and
UBS for a Hong Kong IPO, _GlobalCapital Asia_ understands.

Founded in 2013, New Horizon Health manufactures home kits for screening colon
cancer, designed to catch signs of the disease early.

The company is backed by numerous investors, including Chinese venture capital
specialist Qiming Venture Partners, China-focused private equity firm
FountainVest Partners, Softbank's SB China Capital and US research university
Duke University.

New Horizon Health most recently raised $20m through a series D financing
round in April, bringing its total investment so far to $130m.

With Kintor Pharma's IPO priced, New Horizon Health would follow at least four
firms out of the Chinese healthcare sector this year, including InnoCare
Pharma, Akesobio and Peijia Medical. The trio floated for HK$2.2bn, HK$2.6bn
and HK$2.3bn, respectively.

title: Kintor Pharma prices IPO high to net $240m
html:
The Mainland-based firm hit the market last week, following three other Chinese healthcare-related issuers that have listed in Hong Kong since March. The sector has been defiant through the coronavirus crisis, remaining one of the few popular sectors, running counter-cyclical to downward trending global financial markets.

Kintor Pharma kicked off bookbuilding with sole sponsor Huatai Financial and global co-ordinators CICC and UBS on May 12. They took orders for the deal through a four-day virtual roadshow.

The trio – working alongside bookrunners CCB International, China Everbright Securities, China Renaissance Securities, CMB International and Haitong international – marketed 92.3m shares at HK$17.80 to HK$20.15 apiece. The price guidance meant it could raise anywhere from HK$1.64bn to HK$1.86bn from the IPO.

Kintor, a clinical-stage novel cancer drug developer, came to the market to raise funds for developing and commercialising its core products.

To set the IPO on a good base and boost confidence in the deal, the company placed 48% of the offer with four cornerstone investors. The majority was taken by Chinese state-backed Zhuhai Gree Financial Investment Management, which subscribed for $98m.

Entities Cherry Cheeks and Highlight Medical, both indirectly controlled by pre-IPO investor Stephen Hui Wang, took $7m and $5m, respectively. Chinese investment bank DFZQ, also known as Orient Securities, claimed $5m of the deal.

After bookbuilding through to the end of last week, the syndicate wrapped up the deal. Thanks to the horde of institutional and retail investors, the leads were able to price the IPO at the top of the range, according to a source close to the deal.

The institutional book had over 120 long-only investors, healthcare specialists, hedge funds and high net worth accounts. But Hong Kong retail investors subscribed their portion of the deal over 500 times, triggering the full clawback – a mechanism that reallocates stock to retail based on the level of demand.

The full clawback left just $41m of the IPO for institutional investors. And with half going to the top 10 accounts – a mix of long only investors and healthcare specialists – a larger number of investors got zero allocation of the stock, according to the source.

Kintor’s shares will go live at HK$20.15 apiece on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange on May 22. The deal also includes a 15% greenshoe of 13.9m shares.

The issuer will invest 70% of the IPO proceeds in the development and commercialisation of its core products. Kintor’s lead drug is Proxalutamide, which is undergoing trials related to prostate cancer and breast cancer.

The firm will also put 20% of the proceeds towards clinical and pre-clinical stage drug candidates and study projects, and use the balance for working capital and other general corporate purposes.

Kintor has suffered somewhat from the Covid-19 pandemic, with the forced closure of its Miami-based clinical trial centre. The company warned in its prospectus that it cannot assure Covid-19 will have no further impact on its business, but it does not expect to make any “material deviation” from the development of its drugs.

Kintor is controlled by co-founder and chief executive Youzhi Tong and co-founder Chuangxing Guo. Following the IPO, the duo’s aggregate stake in the company has been diluted from 36.84% to 27.64%.

New Horizon Health mandates for IPO

Chinese biotechnology firm New Horizon Health has mandated Goldman Sachs and UBS for a Hong Kong IPO, GlobalCapital Asia understands.

Founded in 2013, New Horizon Health manufactures home kits for screening colon cancer, designed to catch signs of the disease early.

The company is backed by numerous investors, including Chinese venture capital specialist Qiming Venture Partners, China-focused private equity firm FountainVest Partners, Softbank’s SB China Capital and US research university Duke University.

New Horizon Health most recently raised $20m through a series D financing round in April, bringing its total investment so far to $130m.

With Kintor Pharma’s IPO priced, New Horizon Health would follow at least four firms out of the Chinese healthcare sector this year, including InnoCare Pharma, Akesobio and Peijia Medical. The trio floated for HK$2.2bn, HK$2.6bn and HK$2.3bn, respectively.
